question: Question_05_(a)
statement:
Find the general solution $\vec{x}(t) = \left[ \begin{array}{c}
x(t) \\ y(t) \end{array} \right]$ of the homogeneous linear system

\[\vec{x}' = A \vec{x}, \qquad A = \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 0 & 3 \\ 2 & 1 \end{array} \right],\]

and sketch the phase portrait (i.e. some typical trajectories in the
$xy-$ plane).
sols:
We begin by finding the eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

The characteristic polynomial of
$\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$ is
$\lambda^2 - \lambda - 6 = (\lambda - 3)(\lambda + 2)$ which has roots
$\lambda = 3, -2$. The find the eigenvector with eigenvalue $\lambda$,
we seek the nullspace of $A - \lambda I$.

With $\lambda = 3$, we have:

\[\begin{bmatrix}-3 & 3 \\ 2 & -2 \end{bmatrix} \vec{v} = \vec{0}.\]

From the equation implied by the first row (the second is redundant),
$-3 v_1 + 3v_2 = 0$ so we can take $\vec{v} = \langle 1,1\rangle$.

With $\lambda = -2$, we have:

\[\begin{bmatrix}2 & 3 \\ 2 & 3 \end{bmatrix} \vec{v} = \vec{0}.\]

From the equation implied by the first row (the second is the same),
$2 v_1 + 3 v_2 = 0$ so we can take $\vec{v} = \langle 3,-2 \rangle$ as
an eigenvector.

The general solution is
$\vec{x}(t) = C_1 \begin{bmatrix}1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} e^{3t} + C_2 \begin{bmatrix}3 \\ -2 \end{bmatrix} e^{-2t}$.

The origin is a saddle point because the eigenvalues are real and of
opposite sign. Along the $\displaystyle \langle 1,1\rangle$ direction,
the solution grows exponentially. Along the
$\displaystyle \langle 3,-2\rangle$ direction, the solution decays
exponentially. At all other points, it will approach the line spanned by
$\displaystyle \langle 1,1\rangle$ as $t \rightarrow \infty$. This is
displayed in the figure.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Wiki5asketch_2013WT1.png}
\caption{Saddle point phase portrait}
\end{figure}
hints:
A good start would be to find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors. This way
you can see how the solution trajectories behave (growing/shrinking) in
different directions.
